period.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a particular length of time with a beginning and an end
period.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Tomorrow’s weather will be dry with sunny periods.
The drug was tested over a five-week period.
They adopted the system for a trial period (=time in which something is tested to see if it works well).
His playing improved in a very short period of time.
period.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a particular time in someone’s life or in history
period.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: the conflict of the Cold War period
the behaviour of children during the period of adolescence
period.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the flow of blood that comes from a woman’s body each month
period.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: I was 12 years old when I started my periods.
period.translation[0].definitions[3].def: the mark (.) used in writing to show the end of a sentence or of an abbreviation
period.translation[0].definitions[4].def: one of the equal parts that the school day is divided into
period.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: What class do you have first period?
period.translation[0].definitions[5].def: one of the equal parts that a game is divided into in a sport such as ice hockey
period.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The Bruins scored twice in the first period.
period.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: They had to spend long periods apart.
He lived for a short period in Manchester.
From May, the site will be open to the public for a limited period.
A tourist visa allows you to stay for a fixed period.
The painting had been loaned to the gallery for an indefinite period.
a six month/five year etc period
They studied the behaviour of the ocean during a five year period.
We could introduce the system for a trial period.
Over a period of time, this pressure can damage the fibres of the carpet.
period.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: a period in history
period
a particular time in history, especially one studied as a subject
the late Victorian period
the interwar period
During that period many people moved from the countryside to the towns.
a period of years, months, days etc
The 1960s were a time of great social change.
the biggest earthquake in modern times
Verdun was an important city in Roman times.
age
a long period, especially one that represents a particular stage in the development of civilization or technology
the industrial age
We are now in the age of the Internet.
the Stone Age (=when people used tools made of stone)
era
a long period that has a particular character or that is marked by particular events
We live in an era of breathtaking change.
the post-war era
De Gaulle’s death marked the end of an era.
epoch
means the same as era, but sounds more formal and important
We are now entering a new epoch in human history.
the colonial epoch
It was the end of an epoch.
period.translation[1].definitions[0].def: used to emphasize that you have made a decision and that you do not want to discuss the subject any more
period.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: She has been taken on for a 6-month trial period.
